reviewText: Words for Evil is a high speed version of single player Boggle.  Instead of a timer, you have adventurers that go in to battle.  There are four different types of puzzles your adventurers will face.  First is the regular battle, where you spell as many words as you can using letters that connect (just like Boggle).  The twist is that in order to progress (cause damage/use abilities), you need to incorporate highlighted letters in to your words.  A minimum of three letters are required for each word, and bigger words have a stronger effect.  Second is the trap puzzle, where you are given letters you need to incorporate in to words, regardless of their placement. reviewText:
Words for Evil is a very fun, low stress casual adventure game set in a fantasy world where all attacks are made by creating words with the letters provided. This game is for those of us who love wordplay and typing in particular. I heard about Words for Evil quite a while before it was available on Steam, and bought an entire bundle and downloaded the Desura client just for this game. I have always enjoyed typing and have an average speed of 101 words per minute, and I write for a living, so this game was instantly on my radar. I am constantly intrigued by video games that incorporate wordplay in any form, but typing quickly in this game is also a plus because it directly affects the attack rates of your party members.

Fluency in typing, whether based in speed or accuracy, is not required, however. Words for Evil will be extraordinarily easy for those of us who can type quickly, but it is designed to be accessible for anyone. It also acts as a tool to encourage the player to both properly spell and accurately type because it is in your best interest to attack the enemy at a faster pace than she or he attacks you.

In a nutshell, Words for Evil plays out like a 2D adventure game where the party members you choose move automatically from left to right. Your party will come across enemies, blacksmiths, potion stores, and traps every few seconds. You can purchase goods to outfit your party from the blacksmiths and potion stores. Every time you come across an enemy, you are given a grid full of letters to choose from. Using gameplay mechanics similar to Popcap's classic Bookworm, you can spell out words via typing them if the letters are in order on the grid (connected vertically, horizontally, and diagonally). Each time you finish a word, your characters attack. By leveling up your characters, you gain access to special attacks that are used by utilizing colored letter squares on the grid. Each defeated enemy gives you XP, and each party member can be upgraded many times. In addition, you'll come across new characters every once in awhile that you may choose to add to your party (in an empty slot or as a replacement for another). There are many characters, special attacks, and even worlds to unlock.

Treasure chest mini-games are vaguely similar to fights, but you are offered two rows of letters, and you must choose one letter in each row to come up with a word by the last column. Do this for all five rows within a time frame (for a five letter word), and you unlock the chest. There are also traps that present you with a grid, and you have to try to use all the letters in various words. Once you use up the letters, they disappear and none replace them; however many letters are left over, unused, dictates how much damage your party is subject to by the trap.

Words for Evil is a casual game. Despite being set in a fantasy world (and a beautiful one, at that; the pixel art here is as gorgeous and colorful as it is simplistic), there is really no story to follow or reason" to traversing the world other than the relaxing joy of it. There is a lot to unlock

reviewText:
A fun game that mixes roleplaying with a word game, requiring at least some degree of skill at literacy. The basic game is simple and fun, and the addition of multiple characters each with powers and levels increases replayability immensely.

The game does get a bit repetitive and I've found that  concentrating on making many fast, small words in quick succession seems to be a far better strategy than going for longer words, which is a bit of a shame. For a word game I would have thought rewarding intelligence and thought above reactions and repitition would have been a better balance. And the chests and traps seem to be heavily influenced by luck: some are very easy while others are staggeringly hard.

Overall, though, it's a nice diversion and definitely worth while picking up even at full price. At the time of writing, Steam says I've played 9.4 hours of Words for Evil. It doesn't seem like it's been anywhere near that long!

Pros:
+Gorgeous visuals
+Excellent sound
+Gameplay mechanics work well and are quite well balanced
+The randomization of the levels is well done
+The characters are persistent, and retain their experience, stats, and upgrades from playthrough to playthrough

To use your character's abilities and deal damage, you must use the colored tiles on the board when you spell a word. Each member of your party has their own color. Using more than one tile of the same color in a single word causes your characters to use more powerful abilities. While you're hunting for words, the opponent is attacking you, slowly wearing down your health. You move from place to place in a neverending randomly generated linear landscape. Most locations will contain a monster to fight, but now and then you'll come across blacksmiths where you can upgrade your stats with weapons and armor, potion shops where you can buy up to three potions (healing, and various types of defense and offense), chests which you open by solving an anagram, traps which you disable by trying to use all the letters in a grid to spell words, and healing fountains where your characters are fully healed and level up their abilities. Eventually, you find the location that unlocks the next level, and you can choose to continue where you are or move on.

Cons:
-Mouse controls can be a little glitchy from time to time (though keyboard controls are also available)
-Gameplay can get a little repetitive, as with any word-based game
-There is no way to view your characters' equipment upgrades, and it's unclear whether they are using only the latest weapon/armor, or if the effects are cumulative; the interface could use some more transparency and better explanation
-The gameplay is so fast-paced that you never have time to look up at your characters and actually watch the battles. It's just a constant hunt for the next word. The action happening above the word box seems to be primarily for the benefit of someone watching you play the game. Would be nice if the speed were tweaked so that the action paused when you spelled a word, long enough for you to see the result.

I've found the pros to vastly outweigh the cons, and I've enjoyed all my time spent on the game. I do hope that the developer will eventually tweak it a bit to resolve some of the issues, but even if they don't, I don't regret having it.

Ever since this game popped up on the main shop front page as a new game, I was curious. I love word games. Words for Evil did not disappoint at all.

It's a walker type game, and you can quit out anytime from the level and keep the progress you've made. You make your own party out of a number of unlockable heroes, including Santa Claus (who is seriously impressive in a fight)! Essentially you're given one of a number of puzzles, depending on whether you are up against a monster, a chest, or a trap, and you have to do your best at figuring them out. It stimulates the mind, and there are RPG elements as well, such as levelling up and buying gear.

I set it on the Zen difficulty and I still find it stimulating and challenging. It's the kind of game that sucks you in and, before you know it, hours have passed. It's so easy to say 'I'll just go to the next fountain' or 'I just want to do a few more battles'.

The graphics are adorable and charming, as well as in some cases quite stunning. The sense of humour in the game is welcome and pleasant. It's also noteworthy that it has a mode for those who may be colour blind or have a deficiency in distinguishing colours, so that's a really important thing.

It's a light game that doesn't take up a lot of space or demand masses of processing power, so it's the perfect game for any system. Some words you'd expect or know may not be in the game's dictionary, but that can just add a little to the challenge. Either way, it's been perfectly delightful for me, and I have no problem recommending it to anyone who likes to think as they play a game.

Charming, fun, and really absorbing, Words for Evil also has a price that can fit into most any budget. It's worth picking up and supporting. I'd love to see more games like this, and I look forward to seeing what the developer does with Words of Evil in future.

I donâ€™t know if anyone else was burning the midnight oil last night, but we knocked this one out pretty quick. Letâ€™s get going shall we?

I â€“ Story [3/10]

Words for Evil is a RPG-like word game from Dylan Loney. WFE doesnâ€™t have much of a story; you (the player) select a hero and slowly gather more heroes as you battle your way through a series of worlds. In each world you must find a shrine to unlock the next and so on and so forth. Pretty basic, but, itâ€™s more of a story than most other word games youâ€™ll probably find out there.

II â€“ UI [10/10]

A good user interface is the heart and soul of any word game and WFE is no exception. Also, WFE had a marvelous UI. Every single command in the game can be issued through the keyboard. You can use a mouse as your primary source of input or in a more supplemental role, but that will become arduous in a hurry. WFE handles like smoother than a fish in water, so bravo to Mr. Loney on his excellent work in this aspect.

III â€“ Gameplay [8/10]

If youâ€™ve played one word game, youâ€™ve practically played them all. WFE has two styles of word games youâ€™ll encounter during play. The first (similar to Boggle or Bookworm) presents you with a table of letters with which you construct words. Once the letters are used, they are removed from the table and new letters take their place. The second style of game is more of a jumble. You are given a series of letters and you must find the word or words hidden within them. Seems familiar right?

Here is where WFE shakes things up. Battle sequences use the first style of play. On the letter table, certain letter tiles will have different colors. These colors correspond to one of you heroes. If you create a long enough word that features one or more tiles of the same (or different) colors, the corresponding heroes will launch an attack on the enemy. In the event that your party of heroes runs up against a trap, a treasure chest, or (Cthulhu forbid) one of them falls in battle, youâ€™ll be presented with a game of the second play style.

My only real complaint with the gameplay was with the jumbles used on treasure chest encounters. Some of the words you are presented with and tasked with unscrambling are either archaic or youâ€™ll never have heard of them before in your entire life. It accounts for some mild annoyance, but the gameplay itself remains solid.

IV â€“ Content [10/10]

Normally, all youâ€™d expect out of a game such as WFE is a dictonaryâ€™s worth of words. This, however, is not the case. As I mentioned above, WFE is an RPG-like word game. There are 19 unlockable heroes, 84 different enemies, 6 worlds, and a small collection of items to upgrade your heroes with. At itâ€™s core, WFE is still a word game at the end of the day, but the extra content really breaks up the long-term monotony of the genre.

V â€“ Visual [8/10]

WFE has charming art, but some of the animations happen so incredibly fast, it is almost impossible to see what is happening during the battle. The environments are beautiful and very detailed.

VI â€“ Audio [8/10]

I quite enjoyed the music of WFE. It fit well with the atmosphere of the game and with the theme of each world. You couldnâ€™t ask for more of any game. Some of the sound effects become a bit repetitive after a while though, but, if you get into the zone, you shouldnâ€™t even notice.

VII â€“ Overall [7.8/10]

Overall, Words for Evil is a fun game and a great way to kill some downtime. At only $2.99, it is an absolute steal as well. A word puzzle game sporting a minimal interface and an RPG feel. Gets a bit repetitive after awhile, but still fun to play.

Starting with a single adventurer, you journey through the land using your vocabulary to power your skills and defeat monsters you encounter on the path. You travel between worlds, encountering different monsters and other adventurers who can join your party. The general game has enemies which attack you in real time, turning your adventurer's health bar into something of a time. You attack by link letters on a grid to form words, using colored tiles associated to power your adventurer's attacks. The game is best played with a keyboard: Typing will not only select the tiles for you, it will change the selection based on the word your type, relinking letters, and prioritizing colored tiles. The only time I even touched the mouse was while selecting adventurers. In addition to the main puzzle, there are a few mini-puzzles used for activities like looting chests and disarming traps.

The RPG aspect of the game has your adventurers gaining experience after every encounter, which can be used to level up their abilities. There is also gold used to purchase potions and items at various shops along the way, which I think is where the game starts to falters. The potions work well, enough, but the equipment doesn't seem to do much. Gear looted from chests is either randomly assigned, or possibly shared between party members; either way, the game doesn't do a very good job of explaining how it works. Gear can be assigned when purchased from a merchant, but there's no way I could find to see what the adventurer's was currently carrying, or compare it to what was being purchased. I'm assuming this means that whatever bonuses given simply stack, even if the old gear is completely replaced.

The only other downside in my opinion is the repetition. Part of this is inherent to the genre: How many letter grids can you look at before it starts to get a little boring? For it's part, the game does a pretty good job mixing up the puzzle types, and the RPG aspect does help a bit. That said, this game feels a bit too easy. The puzzle difficulty feel static, and you can win almost any fight using only three letter words, especially using the keyboard to pound them out. Enemies don't seem to be very powerful. You might lose an adventurer once in awhile, but very rarely will you lose the entire party.

Think Bejeweled tile based gameplay meets scrabble and then run across some shops, buy some buffs, and stagger by new characters to appear like an RPG.

Its a weird combo, but unique enough that for $3 it caught my eye. I thought I would get bored but mixing in 'Traps' and 'Treasure Chest' minigames keep things pretty interesting. There is an odd Challenge to the game, especially once you start unlocking extra attacks with your multiple party members.

I will leave you with this, If you like typing games, then absolutly buy it. If you dont like typing games but simple RPG elements and have some time to kill, I think you'll be pleasantly surprised.

Words for Evil isn't bad game, but isn't also the best I have played when it comes to typing/spelling games. First of all, it have some issues - sometimes, while making a longer word, it just clear letters I used. Sometimes, also when I'm trying to make some longer word, if there is shorter version of it, for some reason by itself it makes this word, ignoring what I want to do. Well, those stuff probably isn't much of deal but this game isn't very interesting. Best tactic? Make short words only. It's get boring really fast and sure, I can try harder and make only longer words but sadly this game isn't turn based but real time, so if you spend longer time trying to make some nice word, you will probably get killed very fast. Some sounds in game are too loud (even with sliding it to lowest), graphics aren't really interesting or beatiful, not like it really matter but you can feel that something is missing.\nIf you are fan of this kind of games, if you get bored with every other game from this genre avaible on Steam, maybe you could try it.
